title: Excavated at Last! What Archaeology Could Reveal About Colossians.
description:
For the first time in history, archaeologists are excavating the ancient city of Colossae, the very place Paul addressed his letter to the Colossians and to Philemon. Dr. Arnold explains the significance of Colossae in the New Testament world, the challenges of getting an excavation approved in modern Türkiye, and what discoveries could reveal about the spiritual and cultural background behind Paul’s warnings to the Colossian church. From mosaics hidden under farmland to ground-penetrating radar scans that point to buried temples, this is a fascinating look at how history, archaeology, and Scripture intersect.

title: God is NOT An Exception
description:
The answer: Only things that begin to exist need a cause.
God, by definition, is eternal—He didn’t begin, so He doesn’t need a cause.

title: Are all Bible Versions Equally God-Breathed Scripture?
description:
Christians across traditions—Catholic, Orthodox, and Protestant—sometimes differ on which books are considered inspired Scripture, especially when it comes to the Apocrypha.

But here’s the key: all major branches agree on the 27 books of the New Testament. And those are more than enough to understand who God is, how He revealed Himself, and how we’re called to follow Him.

Even if we don’t accept certain books as authoritative, we shouldn’t shy away from reading them. Explore their history, ask who wrote them, and consider what they teach. Truth can handle honest questions.

Even under the brutal Roman system, where executions weren’t about preference but humiliation—Peter’s death echoes the hope and power of Jesus.

title: Did God Abandon Jesus on The Cross?
description:
When Jesus cried out, “My God, my God, why have You forsaken Me?” was He truly separated from the Father? That line often stirs confusion, especially when we affirm the unity of the Trinity. But Jesus was quoting Psalm 22—a psalm of David that begins in anguish but ends in hope. Just like David, Jesus expresses the deep feeling of abandonment, yet knows the Father is still at work. This isn't a breakdown in the Trinity. It's a fulfillment of prophecy, a window into the emotional and spiritual weight Jesus carried on the cross—for us.

title: Was The Early Church REALLY Persecuted?
description:
Some people claim persecution of early Christians was exaggerated or even fabricated—but that’s simply not true. While there wasn’t always empire-wide persecution, the cost of following Jesus was real. Just read the New Testament. Over and over again, it’s clear: living for Jesus came with a price. Outside the Bible, sources like Tacitus and Pliny the Younger confirm that Christians were targeted—especially in Rome under Nero. They were mocked, hated, even blamed for disasters. This wasn't made up by Christians. It was part of what it meant to proclaim the risen Jesus in a hostile world.

title: Why did they choose Barabas?
description:
Why would a crowd choose to release Barabbas—a violent criminal—over Jesus, who was innocent? It’s a hard question, but I think it reveals something deep about human nature. In John’s Gospel, Pilate is clearly trying to get out of crucifying Jesus. He finds no guilt in Him. Yet the crowd—likely influenced by powerful religious leaders who felt threatened by Jesus—demanded His death. They were spiritually blind. What looked like the end was only the beginning. Jesus’ crucifixion wasn’t a loss of power—it was the greatest display of it.

title: Did Christianity Steal Its Core Stories from Other Religions?
description:
I often hear people say Christianity borrowed its core stories, like the resurrection or the flood, from other religions.

That claim isn’t just wrong; it’s flat-out ridiculous. The resurrection of Jesus is unique in history. There’s no credible evidence that Christianity borrowed this from other faiths.

While flood stories exist in various cultures, the details and theological meaning in the Bible are distinct. And the idea that Christmas traditions were “stolen” overlooks the rich history of how Christian festivals developed.

Friends, if you want to understand Christianity, it’s important to separate fact from popular myths. The truth stands up to the facts and the scholarship.

title: How Do We Know Jesus Really Performed Miracles?
description:
I’m often asked how we can trust that Jesus actually performed miracles.

There’s broad scholarly agreement that Jesus was known as a miracle worker. All four Gospels, Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, highlight His miracles as a core part of His ministry.

Even Jesus’ opponents didn’t deny the miracles; they only debated their source. For example, in Mark 3, they suggested Satan was behind it, not that the miracles didn’t happen.

Some miracle stories are unlikely inventions, like Jesus spitting and rubbing mud in a blind man’s eyes. If someone was making this up, why choose such an awkward detail?

Finally, Jesus’ miracles fit perfectly with His teaching and life. The story simply doesn’t make sense without them.

title: Struggling to Read the Bible Consistently? Try This.
description:
Here’s one practical step I’ve found really helpful. Pick a short New Testament book, like Galatians or Ephesians, and read or listen to it in full every day for a month.

If you miss a day, don’t worry about catching up. Just keep going the next day. This approach helps you see the big picture instead of isolated verses. It allows you to notice patterns, themes, and repeated ideas, which helps you really own the book.

After a month, move on to another book. Read about four chapters a day, or maybe eight. This is a way to work through the New Testament with depth, not just speed.

title: Dogs In Heaven?  #Shorts
description:
People often ask me if they’ll see their dog in heaven.

The Bible doesn’t give a direct answer, but I see two possibilities.

One, God in His goodness could choose to bring your dog back in some form, as an expression of His love for you.

Or two, He may not, and yet you’ll be in a perfected state where you recognize that your dog was a gift for a season. And in God’s presence, your heart will be fully satisfied in ways you can’t yet imagine.

Whatever the case, heaven will not lack anything. God’s goodness will be complete.

title: Is God Evil For Sending People To Hell?
description:
“If God sends people to hell, then He never loved them to begin with.” At first glance, that sounds like a mic drop moment. But let’s take a closer look. Hell in the Bible isn’t God setting people on fire, it’s described using metaphors like fire and darkness to represent loss, judgment, and separation from God. The truth is, God’s justice doesn't cancel out His love, it flows from His holiness. These are tough questions, but we can't build theology on emotional analogies. Let's go back to what Scripture actually says.

title: STOP Doing This
description:
“Ask Jesus into your heart.” It’s a phrase many of us grew up hearing, but did you know that exact wording isn’t actually found in the Bible? In Ephesians 3:17, Paul says Christ dwells in our hearts through faith, but when we focus only on emotions, we risk missing the full picture of what conversion truly is. Following Jesus involves our mind, will, and emotions. It’s not wrong to say “invite Him into your heart,” but I think we’re better off using language that reflects the clarity of the gospel.

What happens when a comic book legend sits down to talk faith? I got to interview Rob Liefeld, creator of Deadpool, Cable, and many iconic Marvel characters, to explore the intersection of faith, creativity, and culture. He's had a massive impact on my life and I was so excited to speak to him. Today, he'll talk about his journey in the comic book world and the creation of Deadpool, how his Christian faith has shaped his life and career, what it’s like navigating Hollywood as a believer and 
why storytelling matters and how pop culture can open doors for deeper conversations about truth.

title: How to Answer Tough Questions About Faith
description:
When someone comes to me with a hard question, I try to remember how Jesus responded. He told stories and He asked questions. In fact, we have over 300 questions recorded from Jesus. That’s why I try to lead with questions and listen well. But I also hold onto this truth: even if I don’t have the answer in the moment, there is an answer because Christianity is actually true. We’re called to speak the truth with gentleness and respect. So ask, listen, and stay confident in what’s real.

title: Do Miscarried Babies Go To Heaven? #christianfaith #apologetics
description:
This is one of the hardest questions I get: what happens to babies lost in miscarriage, or people who can’t fully understand the gospel due to mental challenges? I believe God’s grace and mercy cover those who never had the chance to understand. If someone is truly incapable of understanding their own sinfulness, I trust in the goodness of God to do what’s right, even if I can’t fully grasp how. He is just. He is kind. And I believe He is near to the brokenhearted.

title: Don’t Just Tell Your Kids About Jesus #christianparenting
description:
I used to think telling my kids about Jesus was enough. But I’ve learned it’s not just about words, it’s about showing them who He is through Scripture and through the way I live. Want your kids to know Jesus’ compassion? Show them how He healed the leper. Want them to understand His love? Read the story of the Good Samaritan or the prodigal son. But the real question I ask myself is: do my kids see Jesus in me?

title: Is the Soul Real? A Neurosurgeon Makes the Case
description:

Using modern neuroscience and his vast surgical experience, he believes there is a spiritual soul that transcends the brain, using fascinating case studies to prove his claim. Today, he's here to discuss his new book comes out June 3rd.

title: Is Jesus God? Understanding The Trinity #christianityexplained #Trinity
description:
People ask me all the time, are Jesus and God the same? I get it. The Trinity can be confusing. But here’s how I’ve come to understand it: God is one in essence but exists as the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. Jesus is fully divine, but He’s distinct from the Father and the Spirit. It might sound complex, but it’s not a contradiction, it’s what Scripture consistently reveals about God. I don’t believe this because it’s easy to grasp. I believe it because it’s true to God’s Word.

title: Are you Ok Not Knowing?
description:

I’m all about pushing with curiosity and praying for them.

title: Understanding the Trinity
description:
The word “Trinity” isn’t in the Bible—just like the word “aseity” isn’t—but the truth behind it is. God reveals Himself as one in being and three in person: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

It’s not a contradiction—it’s a mystery rooted in Scripture. I don’t believe in the Trinity because I fully grasp it, but because the Bible clearly reveals it. And honestly, if we could completely understand God, He wouldn’t be God.

title: Old Earth Vs. Young Earth
description:
I’ve had a lot of conversations with Christians who hold to either an old earth or young earth view. Personally, I see these as important in-house discussions that shape how we interpret both science and Scripture. What matters most to me is holding to the core truths of the Christian faith.

Old earth and young earth believers often differ on how they understand things like death before the fall—many old earthers, for example, see it as human death that entered after the fall. These views influence how we engage with modern science, but they’re not issues I believe we should divide over. We need grace and clarity as we walk through this together.

title: Should I Use a Preferred Pronoun?
description:
Someone asked me how to handle a situation at work where a young man now wants to be called a female name. I get it—it’s not always simple. Personally, I try to consider the context, the name itself, and my relationship with the person. Some names feel more neutral, and sometimes I’ve found ways to avoid using a name altogether if it doesn’t sit right with me before the Lord. We need wisdom, courage, and a community around us to walk this out well—with both conviction and compassion.

Let me know how you’ve navigated situations like this. You're not alone.

title: What Christianity Teaches About The Body
description:
In a culture that often either idolizes or dismisses the body, Scripture offers a radically different message: the body is good.

From the beginning, God formed us with intention—male and female—and called it very good. Then He took on flesh in the person of Jesus. The incarnation, the resurrection, and even the practice of burial affirm the sanctity of the human body.

Christianity doesn’t teach us to escape the body—it teaches us to honor it, now and into eternity.

title: God Doesn’t Want Your Ability
description:
God doesn’t care as much about your ability as He does about your availability.

Take a look at Saul vs. David, Saul was the obvious pick, the tall, strong, kingly figure. But God chose David, the youngest, the overlooked one, because of his heart. Or think about Moses, he was anything but eloquent, and he doubted himself every step of the way. But when God called him to stand up to Pharaoh, guess who got the credit? God did.

God doesn’t need perfect people; He just needs willing ones. If you feel unqualified or unequipped, you’re in good company. God specializes in using the unlikely to do the impossible.

Is your heart available to God? Let Him use you.

title: Do Dogs Go To Heaven?
description:
Will your dog go to heaven? The Bible doesn’t directly answer, but there are two possibilities: God could bring your beloved dog back because He knows how much you care, or He may not, but you’ll experience a joy so complete that you won’t feel the loss. Heaven is about being fully satisfied in God’s presence, surrounded by greater goods than we can imagine.

title: How Do We KNOW We Have the Right Gospels?
description:
In this video, I explain how we can trust that we have the right books in the Bible, particularly focusing on the Gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. These were written in the 1st century and have the feel of biographies, while later writings from the 2nd and 3rd centuries are more reflective of evolving theology and ideas. The  four Gospels remain the most credible and historically accurate accounts of Jesus’ life.

title: A BIG Debate Behind David & Bathsheba (2 Samuel 11)
description:
Today, we'll cover one of the most controversial stories in the Bible: David & Bathsheba (2 Samuel 11). Did David rape Bathsheba? Was she complicit in any way? Dr. Carmen Imes is an Old Testament professor, writer, and biblical scholar at Talbot School of Theology at Biola University. Hope you enjoy and it can clear up some of the misconceptions and reveal other parts to the story. 

READ: Blame David, Not Bathsheba. Nathan Did, by Carmen Imes: https://www.christianitytoday.com/2022/07/rape-david-bathsheba-adultery-sexual-sin-prophet-nathan/

title: Was Jesus a Failed Prophet? (w/ Darrell Bock)

title: Is IVF Moral? A Christian Debate.
description:
Is In Vitro Fertilization (IVF) ethical? Is there a pro-life way to practice IVF, or should it be entirely out of bounds for Christians (and others)? Dr. Scott Rae is one of the leading Christian ethicists today, he is the author of Moral Choices, and my co-host for the Think Biblically podcast. title: From Klansman Terrorist to Christ
description:
As an ordinary high school student in the 1960s in Alabama, Tom Tarrants became deeply unsettled by the social upheaval and turned to extremist ideology. While attempting to bomb the home of a Jewish leader in Mississippi, Tom was ambushed by law enforcement and shot multiple times during a high-speed chase. After escaping from prison and being caught, he then had a crushing experience of the weight of his sin and became a Christian while in solitary confinement. Now he's a co-pastor of a racially mixed church and became the president of the C. S. Lewis Institute, where he devoted himself to helping others become wholehearted followers of Jesus. Please check out and share his amazing story.

READ: Consumed by Hate, Redeemed by Love: How a Violent Klansman Became a Champion of Racial Reconciliation by Tom Tarrants (https://amzn.to/3AozyLw)

title: Surviving the Indian Ocean Tsunami at 13: A Supernatural Account
description:
Monica Connelly was vacationing on a beach in Thailand with her parents on Dec. 26, 2004, when the Indian Ocean Tsunami struck the shore. She struggled to get her bearings underwater as she tried to reach the surface. Connelly was unable to breathe and her whole body was in pain, but she could "feel like this was God guiding me. “Surviving A Tsunami At Thirteen: A Memoir” was published this fall and details her experience. She joins me to discuss that fateful day from 20 years ago and how she believes God supernaturally saved her life.

title: Escaping a Pseudo-Christian Polygamous Cult (w/ Naomi Wright) #testimony #christianity #shorts
description:
Naomi Wright is the daughter of a pseudo-Christian cult leader. She was raised, yet hidden, within mainstream culture and public school education, where no one knew or the few with a sense of something, stayed silent. Now she holds a Master's of Science in Social Work from the University at Buffalo and is a licensed mental health professional in the state of Colorado. She was raised, yet hidden, within mainstream culture and public school education, where no one knew or the few with a sense of something, stayed silent. Now she holds a Master's of Science in Social Work from the University at Buffalo and is a licensed mental health professional in the state of Colorado. She also holds a Master of Arts in Christian Studies from Denver Seminary. Her areas of speciality include grief and loss, spiritual abuse, including cult abuse, as well as biblical and theological studies.

description:

title: Same-Sex Unions and Christianity
description:
What happened at the Unconditional Conference, which was hosted by Andy Stanley at Northpoint Church? What are some positive takeaways and what are some areas of concern? What is the strategy behind the conference and what effect will it have on the church? Our guest today, Alan Shlemon, went to the conference and will give us an inside look. We also address questions such as (1) Should the church make an accommodation for same-sex unions as it seemingly has for divorce? (2) Are same-sex unions and transgender identities issues we can agree to disagree over?

title: The Surprising Genius of Jesus (ft. Peter Williams)
description:
“Genius” is often not the first word that comes to mind when people think about Jesus. But when studied in detail, Jesus’s teachings portray brilliance. In “The Surprising Genius of Jesus,” Dr. Peter J. Williams examines the story of the prodigal son in Luke 15 to show the genius, creativity, and wisdom of Jesus’s teachings. This interview is meant to strengthen Christians’ confidence in the intellectual fortitude of Jesus and to challenge skeptics to reconsider how they view him.

What happened at the Unconditional Conference, which was hosted by Andy Stanley at Northpoint Church? What are some positive takeaways and what are some areas of concern? What is the strategy behind the conference and what effect will it have on the church? Our guest today, Alan Shlemon, went to the conference and will give us an inside look. We also address questions such as (1) Should the church make an accommodation for same-sex unions as it seemingly has for divorce? (2) Are same-sex unions and transgender identities issues we can agree to disagree over?

WATCH: What Does the Bible Say about Homosexuality? Sean McDowell and Matthew Vines in Conversation: (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yFY4VtCWgyI&t=5820s)

WATCH: Has "Homosexual" Always Been in the Bible? (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=noXmiLzbhPY&t=10s)

READ: Pro-Gay Theology, the Film 1946, and the Multiverse, by Alan Shlemon: https://www.str.org/w/pro-gay-theology-the-film-1946-and-the-multiverse

READ: Chasing Love: Sex, Love and Relationships In A Confused Culture, by Sean McDowell (https://amzn.to/3LKh0rG)

title: Why Grace is Still Amazing (25-year update!)
description:
One of the most impactful books in my own personal life is getting an update after 25 years! Millions of lives have been changed by award-winning author Philip Yancey's startling exploration of grace at street level. Grace is the one thing the world can't duplicate, the healing force we need, and the key to transforming a broken world. With powerful stories, rich theology, and practical suggestions, Yancey challenges us to become living answers to a world that desperately needs to know, What's So Amazing About Grace?

title: The Rise of Social Justice Ideology (ft Neil Shenvi & Pat Sawyer)
description:
Where Are Critical Theory and the Social Justice Movement Taking Us? Critical theory and its expression in fields such as critical race theory, critical pedagogy, and queer theory are having a profound impact on our culture. Contemporary critical theory’s ideas about race, class, gender, identity, and justice have dramatically shaped how people think, act, and view one another—in Christian and secular spheres alike. Authors Neil Shenvi and Pat Sawyer illuminate the origins and influences of contemporary critical theory, considering it in the light of clear reason and biblical orthodoxy. 

Critical Dilemma: The Rise of Critical Theories and Social Justice Ideology (https://a.co/d/07swyEx)

title: Unraveling 7 Mormon Generations of Mormon Faith
description:
What lessons can Christians learn from a former Mormon? Can we take lessons from Corey Miller in responding to Mormonism? After 7 generations of being a Mormon Corey Miller converted to Christianity in 1988. He has since served on pastoral staff at four churches and has taught nearly 100 college courses in philosophy, theology, rhetoric, and comparative religions at various places. title: The Latest Textual Discoveries of the Bible (ft. Dan Wallace)
description:

title: How to Become a Professional Apologist (ft. Dr. Craig Hazen)
description:
What are some ways to make a living as an apologist? Whether teaching, speaking writing, YouTube or some other means, Sean and Dr. Craig Hazen (founder of the Biola MA in Christian Apologetics) discuss different ways to find a career in apologetics. title: An Ivy-League Scientist Becomes a Christian
description:
Tom Rudelius was immersed in his physics studies at Cornell and never thought much about God until his brother, a new convert to Christianity, challenged him to explore faith. He had science and an Ivy League pedigree—why did he need God? He reluctantly began exploring the Bible and the life of Jesus. Seeking proof of God’s existence, he found himself in a world of uncertainty, faced with plenty of reasons for both faith and doubt. While Tom never found absolute proof of God or Christianity, he ultimately concluded that the existing evidence for both is compelling and compatible with science. 

Chasing Proof, Finding Faith (by Tom Rudelius): https://a.co/d/57jyBLd

title: Murder is NOT inhumane. Let me explain...
description:
Murder is NOT inhumane. It’s terribly wrong but not inhumane. How so?

When I was in high school I was watching the news with my dad and we saw a violent, terrible murder. “That’s inhumane,” I said. I’ll never forget how my dad responded:

“Son, that’s not inhumane. Inhumane means not human. That murder was committed by a human being.”

That was one of first times I thought: “It’s humans who commit murder. I’m a human being. Do I have that capacity within me?”

Jesus would say it is out of the heart that comes all sorts of sinfulness.

Matthew: 15:18-20
18 But what comes out of the mouth proceeds from the heart, and this defiles a person. 19 For out of the heart come evil thoughts, murder, adultery, sexual immorality, theft, false witness, slander. 20 These are what defile a person…”

All of us are capable of great evil.

Yes, a murder is awful and one of the worst things we can do. 

However, it is not inhumane because it is human beings who often murder.

⬇️ ⬇️ ⬇️

title: If God, how did JESUS not know THIS?
description:
"Who touched me?" If Jesus is God, why does He ask questions? Couple things to note:

1. Asking a question doesn't imply you don't know the answer.

As a teacher and a parent, I ask my kids and students a lot of questions not because I don't know the answer but because I want them to learn something. 

2. Jesus often asks questions to draw out the faith of others. 

So what was Jesus maybe doing in the circumstance of the bleeding woman (Luke 8:43-48)? 

He was drawing out her faith: 
47 And when the woman saw that she was not hidden, she came trembling, and falling down before him declared in the presence of all the people why she had touched him, and how she had been immediately healed. 48 And he said to her, “Daughter, your faith has made you well; go in peace.”

Then when healed, she could be an example to others of the goodness and identity of Jesus. 

⬇️ ⬇️ ⬇️

title: “Jesus was an EGOMANIAC!” 🤯
description:
“Jesus was an egomaniac!" He told people to worship him and value relationship with him more than any human relationship.

His own words in Matthew 10:37: “Whoever loves father or mother more than me is not worthy of me, and whoever loves son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.”

So does this make Jesus an EGOMANIAC?

If Jesus was merely a human being, then yes. However, Jesus is not just a human being. He is the eternal, perfect, all-knowing, self-existing God who took on human flesh!

When we see a mountain, we should be in awe of its beauty. Likewise, when we see the eternal God in human flesh, we should prioritize this relationship. 

The amazing thing is when we love God first through the Person of Jesus, we are actually in a better position to love other people around us because we won’t idolize them. 

⬇️ ⬇️ ⬇️

title: Were the Apostles of Jesus Mistaken? (Nahoa Life is Back!)
description:
Can we have confidence the apostles had a resurrection-faith until their dying breath? Maybe the apostles were sincere but mistaken. Maybe they were motivated to suffer for a good cause. In this interview, Sean is put on the "hot seat" by Nahoa Life, a brilliant young man, who asks some outstanding questions about the apostles of Jesus.

title: 11 Archaeological Finds for the Gospels (Dr. Titus Kennedy)
description:
Dr. Titus Kennedy is back to join me with his top 10 archaeological discoveries and his response to one challenge against the reliability of the Gospels. From the discovery of the Herod Coins to the Temple Building in John 2, we talk about the many artifacts and findings that have shed light on the events and places mentioned in the Gospels. Join us for some more context, analysis of the historical and cultural setting of the Gospels, and a deeper understanding of the texts.

title: Discovering the Lost City of Sodom (w/Dr. Steve Collins)
description:
How strong is the archaeological evidence for the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah at Tall el-Hammam? Our guest for this episode is Dr. Steven Collins, an author, professor, and leading archaeologist who has logged over 25 excavations in Israel, Palestine, and Jordan. He is Director of the School of Archaeology at Veritas International University, and serves as Consulting Research Professor in the College of Archaeology, Trinity Southwest University.

title: Evil. Hell. Slavery: 10 Challenges to Faith
description:
In this video, I'm tackling the top 10 objections to Christianity that I often hear from skeptics and nonbelievers. I'm joined by Doug Groothuis who is a Christian theologian, philosopher, and author who has a Ph.D. in philosophy. He has taught at Denver Seminary in Colorado and has written extensively on topics related to apologetics, theology, and philosophy. Some of his books include "Unmasking the New Age," "Christian Apologetics: A Comprehensive Case for Biblical Faith," and "On Jesus." He is also a speaker and has spoken at conferences and events on topics related to faith and apologetics. We discuss topics from the problem of evil and suffering, to the death and resurrection of Jesus, I'll be addressing these objections head on and offering some helpful responses and perspective. Whether you're a Christian looking to better understand and defend your faith, or someone simply seeking to better understand the Christian worldview, I hope this video is helpful for you! 

Make sure to subscribe and check out some of my other videos for more on Christianity, Theology and other aspects of culture!

title: Friends. War. Sports: Young C.S. Lewis
description:
CS Lewis. Many know him from his Chronicles of Narnia series or many of the other books and works that he's made. But what  childhood experiences of C.S Lewis shaped him into becoming a prolific writer? What parts of his early life had the greatest impact on his life? Which people and books influenced his thinking, his conversion from atheism to Christianity, and his later writing career? Join me in welcoming back Harry Lee Poe, a C.S. title: 16 Questions On Heaven (with Randy Alcorn)
description:
Are there animals and pets in Heaven? Sports? Can we fly? Can we sin? How does the truth of Heaven help us grieve through loss? Today, my guest Randy Alcorn helps us wrestle through some of the toughest and most common questions about heaven and the promises of the new creation! 

READ: The Promise of the New Earth, by Randy Alcorn (https://www.amazon.com/Promise-New-Earth-Randy-Alcorn-ebook/dp/B0BG9G1DD9)
(https://store.epm.org/the-promise-of-the-new-earth/)

TIMESTAMPS:
How did your belief in Heaven frame your loss of your wife? (1:00)
How do you deal with doubt? (3:31)
What gives you hope? (6:02)
Is Heaven real? (8:26)
How will Heaven be exciting if there’s no risk? (13:25)
Are there animals in Heaven? (16:40)
How about our pets? (20:15)
How can we enjoy Heaven if some of our loved ones are not there? (22:53)
Can people sin in Heaven? (26:53)
Will there be external temptation? (29:50)
Are there sports in Heaven? (34:12)
Will we eat and drink in Heaven? (38:00)
Will we be able to fly? (41:02)
How will our bodies be similar/different in the eternal Heaven? (45:06)
How old will we be in Heaven? (48:30)

title: Celebrities for Jesus (with Katelyn Beaty)
description:
In this video, I interview Katelyn Beaty, a journalist, editor, and keen observer of trends in the American church. She has written for the New York Times, the New Yorker, the Washington Post, Religion News Service, Religion & Politics, and The Atlantic and has commented on faith and culture for CNN, ABC and many more. 

Her new book Celebrities for Jesus, she talks about how Christian leaders use their fame and influence to great effect. Whether that popularity resides at the local church level or represents national or international influence, many leaders have effectively said to their followers, "Follow me as I follow Christ." But fame that is cultivated for its own sake, without attendant spiritual maturity and accountability, has a shadow side that runs counter to the heart of the gospel. 

Make sure to subscribe and check out some of my other videos for more on Christianity, Theology and other aspects of culture!

title: 20 Archaeological Finds for the Old Testament (with Titus Kennedy)
description:
What are the top archaeological discoveries that support the Old Testament? Do finds both illuminate and support the reliability of the Bible? In this video, Sean talks with field archaeologist Dr. Titus Kennedy about 20 discoveries that span the breadth of the Old Testament Scriptures. Here's the 20 finds:

0:00 Intro
2:08 Atra-Hasis (Simmonds Ark Tablet) 
5:12 Code of Hammurabi
7:40 Papyrus Brooklyn
9:43 Weighing of the heart (42 Negative Confessions, Hunefer)
11:50 Nomads of Yahweh
14:04 Jericho scarab (Amenhotep III)
17:02 Merneptah Stele (aka Israel Stela)
19:36 Piym weight
21:23 Tel Dan Stele (House of David)
23:23 Khirbet Qeiyafa ostracon
25:07 Shoshenq I stele (Megiddo)
27:48 Mesha Stele (aka Moabite Stone)
29:30 Black obelisk of Shalmaneser III
31:10 Bulla of Isaiah (the prophet?)
33:00 Sennacherib Prism (Taylor Prism, Oriental Institute Prism, Jerusalem Prism)
36:06 Nebo-Sarsekim tablet
38:04 Jerusalem Chronicle (ABC 5)
39:34 Babylon “ration tablets” (Jehoiachin=Yaukin=Jeconiah)
41:31 Cylinder of Nabonidus
43:58 Geshem king of Qedar (Qaynu bowl)

READ: Unearthing the Bible, by Titus Kennedy (https://amzn.to/3MhAWAc)

WATCH: The Archaeological Evidence for Jesus (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hXN6E3MeMbk)

2. If Caesar's image is on the coin, where is God's image? (See Gen 1:26)
3. What is the scope of Caesar's authority? What is the scope of God's?

title: Is "Homosexuality" A Bad Translation?
description:
YOUTH WORKER DISCUSSION GUIDE:
1. The NASB translation of 1 Corinthians 6:9-10 (1968) simply says "homosexuals." What weakness does that translation have?
2. In our day "homosexuality" may refer to several things: same-sex attraction, sexual orientation, sexual identity, or behavior. Which of these does Paul have in mind? 
3. What cue in the text points to behavior? 
4. Sean suggests that "same sex sexual behavior" communicates Paul's intent. Compare recent translations: NIV, ESV, NET (see translation notes), NLT, CSB, CEV and HCB. Which are clearer? Which focus on behavior?

title: Does God Promise to Heal America? Top Misunderstood Verse #5 (2 Chronicles 7:14)
description:
YOUTH LEADER DISCUSSION GUIDE:
Knowing the audience for a verse is important for understanding it. The context is 2 Chronicles 7:11-22.
1. Who is God speaking to when he makes this promise and what is the occasion? See verses 11-12.
2. Verses 13-18 echo the blessings in Deut. 28:1-14, and verses 19-22 echo the curses in Deut. 28:15-68. Who was the recipient of Mosaic covenant given in Deut. 27-28? 
3. Why should we think the blessings and curses in 2 Chron. 7 apply to nations in our day? How does God bless all nations today? 
4. As in this passage, God wants us to seek him and repent. If Israel repented God promised to forgive their sins and heal their land. What does the New Testament promise to those who repent? See Acts 2:38-39.
